attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Length of feature in internal units.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Name of the country or subnational area (administrative division).

Concatenation of all administrative division names separated by underscores ("_"), beginning with the country name and ending with the division name for the lowest subnational administrative order (level). The field serves as one for name sorting and ordering.

Identical subnational area identifiers in the Excel table, geospatial data file, and Unicode text table, enabling linkage (joining) of the table records to the geospatial data file polygons as attributes.
First-order administrative division name (ADM1), i.e., districts.
Administrative level "0" (ADM0/country); administrative level "1" (ADM1); administrative level "2" (ADM2); administrative level "3" (ADM3); administrative level "4" (ADM4).
Any notes about Uganda or its subnational divisions, which may include former names or alternate names or spellings.
U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) Standard (for country and first-order administrative divisions only).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC), 2020

attr.attrdef: U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS) code (for country and first-order administrative divisions only).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS), 2020

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Annual Five-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for 2000 to 2025 for the national and first-order administrative division levels of Uganda were prepared by the U.S. Census Bureau for joining (linking) to shapefiles as attribute data. The estimates are consistent with the midyear national projections from the U.S. Census Bureau International Data Base (IDB).
dataIdInfo.idPurp: The U.S. Census Bureau is providing annual subnational five-year age group population estimates by sex for Uganda for 2000-2025 in a geographic information system (GIS) for users of the Spatial Data Repository, funded by the U.S. President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
CENSUS DATA 2014 Age-Sex Data: National Population and Housing Census 2014, Census Population by District, Age, and Sex. Uganda Bureau of Statistics. Acquired by the U.S. Census Bureau directly from the Uganda Bureau of Statistics. 5-year age and sex data for 19 districts formed after the 2014 census were calculated based on estimates from District Projected Population by Single Year of Age and Sex (2015-2025), available online at http://www.ubos.org/wp-content/uploads/publications/04_2019District_Projected_population_by_single_age_and_sex_(2015-2025).xlsx (accessed September 16, 2020).
2002 Population Total Data: National Population and Housing Census 2002 Main Report, Table C1: Total Population by Sub-County, Sex, Number of Households, and Average Household Size. Uganda Bureau of Statistics, 2005 (print only, not online).
The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of non-U.S. census and survey data.
GEOSPATIAL BOUNDARIES International boundaries coincide with the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues. Available online at http://geonode.state.gov (accessed September 16, 2020). Geospatial data for the first-order administrative divisions of Uganda were downloaded from the Humanitarian Data Exchange, available online at http://data.humdata.org/dataset/uganda-administrative-boundaries-admin-1-admin-3, "uga_admbnda_adm1_ubos_20200824" (accessed September 16, 2020).
The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of boundary placements.
NATIONAL ESTIMATES AND PROJECTIONS U.S. Census Bureau, Population Division. International Data Base, December 2019 release, available online at http://www.census.gov/data-tools/demo/idb/informationGateway.php, accessed September 16, 2020.
NATIONAL AND SUBNATIONAL AREA NAMES AND CODES (1) U.S. National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. NGA GEOnet Names Server (GNS), available at http://geonames.nga.mil/gns/html/ (accessed September 16, 2020). Contains geographic area names from the U.S. Board on Geographic Names and the U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS) codes. (2) U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) Standard. NSG Standards Registry, available at http://nsgreg.nga.mil/genc/discovery (accessed September 16, 2020).

Consts.useLimit: U.S. Census Bureau population estimates: None. Acknowledgment of the Census Bureau would be appreciated in products derived from its population estimates. The subnational boundaries used for this shapefile were downloaded by the U.S. Census Bureau from a publicly available source for this product. The international boundaries are derived from the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset (public domain).

dataIdInfo.suppInfo:
SUBNATIONAL DIVISIONS Uganda's first-order administrative divisions: 135 districts as of 2020 (116 as of the 2014 census and 19 post-census).
SHAPEFILES The original shapefile downloaded from the Humanitarian Data Exchange had 135 polygons and matched the 116 districts from the 2014 census along with the 19 districts formed after the census (first-order administrative divisions) with no changes to the subnational boundaries made by USCB staff. The U.S. Census Bureau aligned the shapefile's national boundary to the Large Scale International Boundary Line (LSIB) polygon file from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues.
CENSUS DATA INTERPOLATION The 2002 census totals had the following differences in geography that have been modified to their 2014 locations in the estimates presented here, requiring interpolation and adjustment of 2002 population data by USCB staff:
(1) There were a total of 60 new districts that were formed between Uganda's 2002 and 2014 censuses, as noted in the USCBCMNT field, with the total number increasing from 56 to 116 districts over the period. New districts were formed from parts of a single area or multiple areas, and boundaries and population data were available for the next administrative level down. The total population of the original area in 2002 was divided according to the populations of the lower-level areas.
The 2014 census data had the following differences in geography that have been modified to their 2020 locations in the estimates presented here, requiring interpolation and adjustment of 2014 population data by USCB staff:
(1) There were an additional 19 new districts that were formed after Uganda's 2014 census, as noted in the USCBCMNT field, with the total number increasing from 116 to 135 districts between 2014 and 2020. 5-year age and sex data for the 19 districts formed after Uganda's 2014 census were calculated by USCB staff based on data from District Projected Population by Single Year of Age and Sex (2015-2025), which contained 5-year age and sex estimates for the new areas. 2014 census data of parent districts were split based on the proportions of each male and female 5-year age group of the newly formed districts, as reported in the post-census estimates.
ADDITIONAL NOTES (1) The National Population and Housing Census 2002 Main Report noted that reported population data for parts of Kotido district were likely incorrect due to "deliberate duplication of households and individuals to inflate the population figures." Likewise, population totals for Kaabong and Karenga districts, which were formed from part of Kotido district, seemed unreasonably high when compared to population totals from the 2014 census, and were assumed to be in error by USCB staff. 2002 population totals for these areas were adjusted downward by USCB staff by reversing growth rate trends from District Projected Population by Single Year of Age and Sex (2015-2025) back to 2002. These adjustments resulted in a net decrease to Uganda's 2002 total census population of 257,892 individuals (about 1.1%), for the purposes of this product. (2) According to the census publications, Moyo and Obongi districts also experienced population loss between 2002 and 2014, but no explanation was included by the Uganda Bureau of Statistics, so the original 2002 census data for these areas were left unaltered by USCB staff. (3) Uganda is divided into four non-administrative geographical regions (Central, Western, Eastern, and Northern) that were not included as part of this product. (4) The original 2014 census single year of age and sex data included the total population for each district.
FEATURE AND ATTRIBUTE DETAILS The 2000-2025 population estimates for Uganda's administrative divisions are provided in the following two tables: (1) The Unicode tab-delimited text file (table) "Uganda_5yr_age_sex_2000-2025_uscb_nov2020.txt," which can be joined to the shapefile via the common field "GEOMATCH." (2) The Excel table "Uganda_5yr_age_sex_2000-2025_508_uscb_nov2020.xlsx," formatted for accessibility in compliance with Section 508 of the U.S. Government's Federal Rehabilitation Act.
Details on processing of the census data and calculation of 2000-2025 estimates are provided in the "Census Metadata" tab of the Excel file and "Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas" document. For the subnational areas, the U.S. Board on Geographic Names (BGN) "approved" names from the NGA GEOnet Names Server (cited in the "Credits") were used. For any area that a BGN name was not available, the name from the national census was used. Official codes for the subnational areas from the country's national statistical office, when available, are entered in the "NSO_CODE" field in both the text and Excel tables. Information on any alternative area names or recent name or boundary changes is entered in the "USCBCMNT" field. A partial list of the fields in the Excel and Unicode text files, including all fields identifying geographic names and codes, is provided in the Excel file's "Data Dictionary" tab. More detail on the U.S. Census Bureau subnational age and sex group estimates and maps for PEPFAR can be found in the document "Subnational Population Estimates Components for the Spatial Data Repository." It includes a data dictionary that is similar to that in the Excel table.
METHODOLOGY For more information, see the following methodology documents in the Spatial Data Repository: (1) "U.S. Census Bureau Methodology for SDR Subnational Population Estimates." (2) "U.S. Census Bureau Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas." (3) "Instructions for Joining Subnational Population Data to Shapefiles."
ACCESS The U.S. Census Bureau’s products for PEPFAR can be accessed from the Spatial Data Repository at http://spatialdata.dhsprogram.com/home/, which also provides access to data and maps from the DHS (Demographic and Health Surveys) Program. A zipped file containing shapefiles with metadata, an Excel workbook with subnational population estimates, and a Unicode tab-delimited text file is available for each country. PEPFAR products are also available on the Census Bureau website at http://www.census.gov/geographies/mapping-files/time-series/demo/international-programs/subnationalpopulation.html for download.
